Installation¶

Q‑Materialise is published on the Python Package Index and can be installed with pip. The project itself is pure Python and does not bundle any particular Qt binding – you choose which binding to install. Because Qt is provided by third‑party packages the library declares a set of optional dependency groups which pull in the appropriate binding for you.

Basic installation¶

The minimum requirement is Python 3.8 or newer. To install the library together with PySide6 (Qt 6 bindings) run:

python -m pip install "q-materialise[pyside6]"

Substitute pyside6 with any of pyqt6, pyside2 or pyqt5 to install the corresponding binding. The extra in the brackets instructs pip to pull in the matching Qt package. For example, to install Q‑Materialise and PyQt6:

python -m pip install "q-materialise[pyqt6]"

If you already have a Qt binding installed you can omit the extra completely; Q‑Materialise will autodetect the available binding at runtime and raise a clear error if none can be found.

Source installation¶

Developers may wish to work with the bleeding‑edge version of Q‑Materialise directly from source. Clone the repository and install it in editable mode using pip. Editable mode ensures that any changes you make to the library are immediately available without re‑installing:

git clone https://github.com/your-user/q-materialise.git
cd q-materialise
# Install the core library and a Qt binding; replace pyside6 as needed
python -m pip install -e .[pyside6]

After installation you should verify that the package can locate a Qt binding by importing it in a Python session:

>>> import q_materialise
>>> from q_materialise import list_styles
>>> print(list_styles())
['indigo_twilight', 'sapphire_day', ...]

If you encounter an ImportError complaining that no supported Qt binding could be imported, install one of the bindings mentioned above.

Choosing a Qt binding¶

Q‑Materialise supports all of the major Python Qt wrappers. When you import the package it searches for a binding in the following order:

  1. PySide6 – the official Qt 6 bindings from Qt Company.

  2. PyQt6 – Riverbank’s Qt 6 bindings.

  3. PySide2 – the Qt 5.15 bindings from Qt Company.

  4. PyQt5 – Riverbank’s Qt 5.15 bindings.

Whichever binding it finds first will be used throughout the library. If you wish to target a specific binding ensure it is installed ahead of the others. On systems where multiple bindings are present the order above determines the winner. You can also bypass binding detection entirely by importing from q_materialise.binding, which re‑exports the QtCore, QtGui and QtWidgets modules from whichever binding was selected.

Uninstalling¶

To remove Q‑Materialise simply uninstall it with pip:

python -m pip uninstall q-materialise

The optional Qt binding packages can be uninstalled separately if desired.
